I think that impressionism is my strength when it comes to art. I find that there's an element of imperfection that is captured by impressionism - a freedom from strictly adhering to logical models of thinkings - that I enjoy quite from time to time. From far away, an impressionist painting may be clearly of a building, or of a boat (or in Monet's case, of lilies) - the subject is often tangible - but on closer examination, you'll find a multitude of 'imperfections' that collectively work together.

Sometimes I think, gee this is kinda ironic, since I'm also an engineer, and can be OCD/think way to hard about the smallest details. I don't mean to sound closed minded, but I think that part of being an engineer requires an unwavering, and sometimes obsessive attention to detail that I sort of let go of when I'm making art. Then, shouldn't I prefer hyper-realistic, accurate and precise, photograph-like depictions? But art is maleable by constitution, and impressionism - for me at least - is more than often a maleable version of concrete things. There's a playfulness, a liberty from utilitarianism about making impressionist pieces for me, and I find it to be cathartic.

I also have many, I would say, po-po-po-post modern, and 'non-formal' (I suppose), mixed media pieces, contact me if you'd like to see more :). I sort of lose it when crafting those pieces - they're a lot of fun if I'm feeling super creative - and would prefer to explain the thinking process and method behind the artwork while I'm showing people.

Oh! Definitely contact me if you'd like some freelance work done. I'm open to most mediums, and I'm definitely not one to turn down a challenge.
